posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
If you/your team used PhotonVision in the 2024/2025 season we would love to hear your feedback below! Like last year we’re going to structure feedback as looking for the good the bad and the ugly:

The good: What worked well? What did you find particularly beneficial to your team? What would you like to see more of?

The bad: What didn’t work? What did you struggle with? What would you like to see changed?

The ugly: What did you have to hack around to make it work for you? What made figuring out the right solution more difficult for you (e.g. wasted precious time)?

We’ll be using this feedback to evaluate priorities during the upcoming offseason. Any feedback is valuable – if we don’t know about it we can’t fix it! As PhotonVision is an open-source community project run by students alumni and working professionals in their free time the best way to see a feature get implemented is to implement it yourself or get someone in the community interested in implementing it. We welcome both ideas and contributors!

The most permanent way to make sure a particular issue doesn’t get lost in the noise is to open a GitHub issue ticket – we’ll be triaging these as we move into the offseason.

We’re also interested in the cameras and coprocessors you’re using. We would appreciate if you can fill out the survey below so that we can identify areas of focus for the offseason.

docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSesrJfPiouxTSdv_Ke2NGHEVVKsnhkQKXqvat85gFQEAUu-wg/viewform?usp=dialog This form is private

Here’s a spreadsheet of all the responses for data analysis: docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JDvl16I2n9pY_JhoOPynfvgrstvxJfTo8WkOWOaWqeA/edit?usp=sharing

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Our overall experience (first-time vision users) was quite positive initially, with smooth integration and functionality achieved quickly during the first lab session after school. However, we encountered intermittent issues with camera connectivity, which became less frequent as the project progressed, ultimately prompting limited reliance on vision systems toward the end of the competition.  

We improved upon this by tilting one camera upward to enhance viewability and faced challenges in determining the appropriate translation matrix for accurate pose detection, which was largely due to our insufficient knowledge rather than a lack of sample resources or guidance. Additionally, we struggled with overheating in a Pi module because it was deployed without adequate cooling solutions, suggesting potential benefits from incorporating heatsinks or fans in future projects. Despite these hiccups, PhotonVision proved successful for us personally and within the team, particularly due to my argument against purchasing integrated vision processors, opting instead for a solution that would meet our needs more effectively and affordably.

posts.name: Sreyan Das
posts.cooked: In the web interface, when "Multetag" Estimation is enabled, certain tags flicker unstably, causing clicks and adjustments to become cumbersome. This issue arises particularly during field calibrations, making it difficult to smoothly adjust settings like exposure and brightness. Additionally, the flickering may relate to screen size constraints, but the consistent occurrence during field work suggests a desire for a solution. The user requests that tag estimates be "hidden" to reduce workflow disruption while in calibration mode.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: When everything was functioning properly, the system proved to be highly reliable and effective. While managing multiple cameras was straightforward, the initial setup using copy-pasted or template code was quick. Calibrating devices minimized trial-and-error thanks to robust calibration features. Device documentation served as an invaluable resource, making complex operations simple. Vision simulation proved to be swift and efficient, adding value without complications. However, challenges arose with camera setups and consistent tagging. Cameras occasionally failed on startup, necessitating frequent resets. Despite setting names/serials, specific USB ports were assigned, complicating troubleshooting due to inadequate device ID handling. Struggles continued with multi-tag filtering, where scaling adjustments were crucial for accurate results. Default settings were too aggressive, causing issues during practice. Object detection training proved demanding, requiring extensive tweaking. An experienced guide would have streamlined the process. Though initially frustrating, the system became dependable and effective upon resolving issues. Satisfaction grew with reliability and precision, solidifying its effectiveness. Future use remains confident.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Could you clarify a little bit about the designated USB ports? The way PV is currently written matches cameras by USB port. That is to say, each camera is connected to the USB port it’s plugged into, and that’s how PV identifies each camera. In regards to Object Detection, that’s in progress for this offseason.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Well, that explains it then. I assumed it'd be binding cameras in the interface to the camera's serial/device ID, since using the arducam serial number tool was in the documentation. I know it's not free with how Linux handles enumeration, but it would add significant robustness. In prior years with Pi-based vision, we'd have folks accidentally swap ports or unplug a camera, resulting in re-enumeration putting the wrong camera in charge of tracking.

posts.name: Lewis
posts.cooked: The system is extremely easy to set up and works exceptionally well. It is significantly more affordable than Limelight, with parts available on Amazon and typically ready for use within a day. Cameras can be individually positioned, swapped, and relocated without the need for complex computational setups. However, the system presents several challenges. There are excessive customization options, leading many teams to feel overwhelmed when deciding on hardware purchases and assessing performance metrics. Additionally, teams often lack knowledge about the importance of calibration, particularly when dealing with multi-camera setups requiring hot swaps. Clear guidance on calibration processes, including multi-tag filtering, prioritization, standard deviation tuning, and object detection, would greatly enhance the system's usability.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: The feedback reveals confusion among teams about hardware selection and performance outcomes. Several teams have queried whether they've reviewed this documentation detailing hardware recommendations and are exploring ways to enhance its clarity or relevance. A potential enhancement could involve creating a more structured guide linked directly to vendor resources.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: In prior years with Pi-based vision, we'd have folks accidentally swap ports or unplug a camera, resulting in re-enumeration putting the wrong camera in charge of tracking. What is old is new again. Welcome back, pre-2025 PhotonVision. It's probably past time we document why we decided to change this behavior this year. The reasons (primarily, not being able to make guarantees about users having cameras with unique serial numbers/UUIDs forcing us to resort to by-usb-port ONLY) are super interesting.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Good results include multitag operations and overall system stability, which has rarely, if ever, lost its configuration randomly in the past year.  

Negative experiences involve camera issues, including potential misidentification due to incorrect port connections leading to significant odometry errors despite unique camera IDs. Additionally, the software reports "camera mismatch" without detailed information or solutions for resolving the issue.  

Regarding improvements, offline photo capture and storage capabilities would greatly enhance calibration accuracy and testing processes. While methods exist for manual filtering and analysis, integrating such features into Photon Vision could streamline and simplify these tasks.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Bad part 2: The details for calibration, and how important calibration is, and how to calibrate multiple camera sets for hot swap really need to be emphasized, put in size 70 font, and bolded. We host workshops for teams teaching them how to go from zero to swerve, and a lot of teams were clueless on how critical it was.

This was pretty frustrating to do on a square checkerboard pattern, and often left the corners with poor coverage on the calibration, and with the board held mostly square to the camera.

posts.name: Lewis
posts.cooked: Some, yes; some, no. Those occasionally confused by the performance chart opt for a less straightforward approach to achieving clear vision. For a quick setup, limiting to Opi 5 with two Arducams for April and one ADU for the piece makes sense. Under calibration, ensure the paper is extremely flat on a clipboard or use an iPad or monitor, printed in bold and size 70.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Got it. All seems pretty tractable for updates. Appreciate it!

posts.name: Bryce Roethel
posts.cooked: Initial setup and calibration for 3 cameras (across 2 co-processors) was painless and took approximately 2 hours. This is our second year using PhotonVision, so we primarily reused our robot-side pose estimation code, which was already well-tuned for filtering vision measurements, thereby significantly reducing the setup time. We implemented the cscore frame time fix and observed no degradation in system performance, contrary to expectations. Despite not rigorously analyzing reported frame latency, we assume the reported ~80% FPS improvement maintained pose accuracy. All our robot logs from the 2025 season are publicly available on GitHub. Notably, we successfully employed both new solve methods: PNP_DISTANCE_TRIG_SOLVE due to its stability and CONSTRAINED_SOLVEPNP with headingFree = true. These methods proved better suited for this year's challenges compared to MULTI_TAG_PNP_ON_COPROCESSOR, as we rarely encountered simultaneous multi-tag observations from a single camera. Our co-processors occasionally failed to boot into the OS, but we resolved this issue by monitoring the status light on the Orange Pi. Relaying instructions to our drive team to power-cycle the device prevented failures. We faced issues with old heading data poising future estimates after pose resets, particularly early in autonomous operations. We mitigated this by clearing the heading buffer manually in our PhotonPoseEstimator. Later, we switched to using constrained solvePNP to determine our initial field position without resetting pose. While this resolved the issue, it may still pose risks for others. We plan to address this in a future PR. Overall, our experience with PhotonVision this year was highly positive, and we look forward to continuing with it. Thank you to the maintainers and contributors for their hard work!

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: I really appreciate you opening a PR to fix the issue with heading resetting. Its community work makes photonvision as good as it is.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Camera calibration was reasonably easy, and configuration proved straightforward, enabling us to achieve highly accurate fusion of vision and odometry pose estimates.

We encountered significant challenges due to issue #1771 affecting the OV9281s' exposure settings. Without a solution, manual flipping of autoexposure was necessary upon robot booting during every competition, which required remembering to do so each time.

In rare cases, about once every 50 matches, either during practice or competition, one of our camera streams would abruptly shut down and reset. This typically occurred when pose accuracy dropped notably. Upon recovery, restarting the camera stream necessitated accessing a browser to re-enable autoexposure, a task our drive coach often addressed promptly. This issue appeared infrequent and unrelated to hardware problems, though we couldn't conclusively pinpoint the root cause.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: That's odd behavior and somewhat concerning. Could you please open an issue and share your logs there? This would greatly help us in attempting to identify the root cause.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Shout out to our drive coach for quick action—the 1 or 2 times this happened in competition—and I think you meant to say one of your human players took this action instead of the drive coach :wink

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
paulonis
posts.cooked: The assistant mentioned that no one intended to take the action, specifically refuting the idea that the drive coach did. The situation occurred during a practice session on Curie where one of the team members missed an opportunity to adjust camera settings correctly after transitioning into teleoperational mode. Despite efforts to improve communication and workflow during subsequent practices, similar issues persisted. While the team explored solutions involving advanced monitoring tools and alternative methods to manage camera streams, ultimately, such fixes were only implemented during at-home training sessions due to the constraints of competition environments.
